headline: Banana Chocolate Chip Cookies
description: These easy banana chocolate chip cookies are a scrumptious combination of mashed ripe bananas, semisweet chocolate chips, and vanilla.
name: Banana Chocolate Chip Cookies

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets.
Sift flour, baking powder, salt, and baking soda together in a large bowl.

Beat sugar and butter together in a separate large bowl with an electric mixer until light and fluffy. Add bananas, eggs, and vanilla; beat to combine. Gradually blend in flour mixture until just combined; stir in chocolate chips. Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto prepared cookie sheets.
Bake in the preheated oven for 12 to 15 minutes. Transfer cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.

review.reviewBody: These cookies are amazing! They taste so amazing with the banana and chocolate mix. Super easy to make and great for any season, occasion or a just because I want to bake!
This is my second batch everyone loves em.
This recipe was perfect! Unfortunately, I didn't have any chocolate chips but as a substitute folded in some walnuts. Made this recipe both ways so far and tasted just as good üëç

I did not read the reviews 1st (silly me) i did preheat my oven to 400‚Å∞ which I felt was wayyy to high, so i overcooked 1st batch, so i than decided tobputy 2nd batch in 2 minutes less still I found still a bit over cooked not as bad as the 1st batch, so 3rd and 4th batch are now in the oven at 350‚Å∞ for 12 minutes. üëå
I like the chewiness of this cookie!

Halved the baking powder/soda, put 4 bananas instead of 3 because it was about to be thrown away and baked at 180 celsius. These small changes should not have resulted in gummy cookies but that's exactly what happened and it was terrible. I like toffee-like cookies, not the risen, gummy type.

I did what other reviews suggested and added only 1 teaspoon of baking powder and used half brown sugar and half white sugar. When hot, these have a more pronounced banana taste, which mellows as they cool. However, they became moist in my cookie tin and were unpleasant because of that. I won't be making these again.

Someone said 400 degrees was too hot for a cookie so I thought about it while I was creaming my butter. Off the top of my head i thought about Russian tea cakes/Mexican wedding cookies that cook at 400 although I think off the top of my head it's only 9 minutes. I only went through a few reviews and didn't see others having a problem with it so I decided to go with the 400. It worked out fine! Also, I used a silicone baking mat instead of greasing the pan. I also love a variety of different kinds of cookies from shortbread to chocolate crinkle (like a brownie) so a cake like cookie is fine with me but I'm glad i was warned. It is very cake like. I think it would be a great cookie to serve at a family brunch.
tasted great but the kids and I added strawberry quick mix to the last 4 cookies lol
Next time I will add 1/2cup brown sugar. Just not as sweet as we are use to. But they are good!!
Yuck what a waste of time and ingredients! This is not a cookie, it‚Äôs more like cake, I should have read the reviews. I gave the whole batch away

This one missed the mark for me. I‚Äôll stick with another recipe that calls for brown sugar and chopped nuts. These are just plain by comparison. They were also more puffy/cake like and I prefer a more chewy cookie.
Did not rise , taste a little bland
I've made this a multitude of times now; it's my go-to recipe for edibles, simply swapping out regular butter for MJ-infused butter.

400 degree oven? ok, I tried. First batch burned to a crisp at 8 mins. Adjusted temp to 375 and second batch was overdone at 10 mins. Not wasting my time again. Good idea to use up bananas, but this recipe is more of a cake than a cookie. Do not recommend.

The taste was good, however the temp is just too high. When they didn't burn on the bottom, they got very brown, while trying to make sure the cookies were baked through. I found another recipe that was very similar the only changes being that it was 3/4 cup butter and called for 1/2 c white sugar and 1/2 cup brown sugar - which I had done in this recipe anyhow. And 2 tsp vanilla, I put 3 in. This recipe may have worked better if it was at a lower temp. The new one that I tried used a temp of 350¬∫ rather than 400¬∫ and they did not burn. Baked at 12 1/2 minutes.

This was my first time baking these cookies. Turned out very cakey rather than cookie like. Ended up looking and tasting like a bunch of small banana pancakes. Not saying this is a bad thing, just wasn‚Äôt what I was expecting. Tasted good though.
I added peanutbutter chips along with chocolate chips and the bananas
They taste soooo good! I used brown butter to make these. I use that in almost everything. Adds that toffee flavor and nuttiness. Delicious!

Cookie tastes good but you're way off regarding the baking temperature. I burnt my first two trays. I lowered the heat to 350 and still using 12 minutes for the baking time and they turned out much better. Fortunately, I had some other baked cookies in the freezer that helped fill a plate to take over to a new neighbor.

Great recipe, just made a few tweaks! I just did 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white sugar, I used 2 ripe bananas. Cooked at 375 for around 10 minutes (I also chose to broil them for a couple minutes to brown the tops a little) They tasted awesome

Not a bad recipe, but needs more details. Def use less baking powder. I reduced to 1 1/2 tsp and they were still very cake-like, almost like a pancake. I also recommend making these very small, maybe silver dollar size, so they can get an even enough browning to get that cookie-like caramelization. 200 C is a little high, but the heat is necessary. I also did half brown sugar half white sugar but all white sugar might be necessary for a crunchier texture. Definitely needs a little tweaking before I'd want to make them again.

I had this recipe before but lost it. We love the cakey almost muffin type consistency and haven't been able to find it since. When I read the reviews and saw one that said it was too cakey, I knew I'd found it again. I also use half white sugar/half brown sugar and we love these! I won't lose this recipe again !
Very cakey! Not a cookie! More like a scone! Very disappointed!!!!
These were great! I reduced the sugar to 1/2 cup and they were perfectly sweet. Didn‚Äôt have choc chip so we used peanut butter chips. On the second batch we added some caramel niblets. So Yummy!

I had an old and lonely banana that wanted to be used and this was perfect. The first time I try a recipe I try to make it as written but I ended up with only 3/4 cup of banana and since I only had 1 cup of chocolate chips I added a cup of shredded coconut. Everything else as written. They were delicious. I had no trouble with the 400 degrees, it all depends on the amount of time. Let me mention it again, the addition of the coconut was DELICIOUS.

Like others said, definitely more of a cake-like cookie. Used chopped chocolate discs because my kids snuck all the chips before I could use them and substituted light brown sugar because I was out of regular. Cooked them at 400 per the directions. Great use of old bananas and leftover chocolate discs.
Loved it! Made it as is but also I used this recipe subbed bananas for applesauce, white sugar for brown sugar and replaced 1/2c. Flour with 1/2c. Oats! AWESOME!!!

Well, the flavor was fine. The cookie texture was very fluffy or airy, unlike a typical chocolate chip cookie. 
Normally don't sift the flour for cookies. Is that a mistake? Is that way they came out airy or fluffy?
I would have preferred they be a little darker also. Use brown sugar instead?
Thanks.

Excellent. My new fave way to use up brown bananas. They came out fluffy and cake-like, which is how I prefer my chocolate chip cookies. I made two minor changes to use what I had on hand: substituted 1/2 cup liquid egg whites because we were out of eggs and used 1 cup of mini-morsel chocolate chips, which was all I had, but that ended up a perfect amount, because the smaller chips distribute well and there was chocolate in every bite still.
This recipe is very easy to make and is not only a family favorite but a great way to use up old bananas.

These were not very "cookie" in their final consistency. They were more like a muffin that you don't cook in a muffin pan. They were very anaemic looking - very pale in colour.
Overall we enjoyed these, warm out of the oven. The kids didn't even mind that there was banana in them which is a bonus.

I made a few changes. 

Less baking powder
4 frozen mushed bananas
1 egg
No vanilla
15 mins usual and 1 minute broiled
Crispy outside, soft inside
Didnt measure chips
Crushed freshly grinded salt
Delicious! I substituted & reduced the white sugar to coconut sugar. I used 3/4 cup coconut sugar & they were scrumptious! I added chopped walnuts to my last batch & they were yummy!
These cookies are delicious!!! Only tweak I made after the first batch was to turn the temp down to 375 degrees for my dark cookie sheet! Came out much better!
Followed the recipe exactly. They were fluffy inside and delicious. Next time we will add some walnuts.
Followed recipe to letter. Great tasting, cake like cookie. My wife loved them.
The flavor is great but the monster level is difficult to balance. In a container they get sticky but uncovered they dry out.
They have a fluffy texture. Didn't modify. Would make again.
These were very simple to make. I took the recommendation to mix 1/2 cup sugar and 1/2 cup brown sugar instead of the cup of sugar. If you want a cookie that is not overly sweet, this one works!
This is a great recipe; quick to make, yielding good flavors. The only adjustment I made was using weed butter in place of regular butter, resulting in some rather potent (adults-only) treats!
I read through the reviews and ended up following mmtammymm's advice. came out wonderfully! trying not to eat more than one cookie before dinner.
I used white chocolate chips instead but whole family lived these cookies.
Very good, just more cake then cookie
Simple and yummy... I had probably 3/4 cup extra mushed bananas so I tossed the extra in too... still worked and tasted amazing... great way to use up ripe bananas

The creaming of the sugar and butter makes the result of this recipe more like banana bread than cookies. Imagine a lump of banana bread batter baked on a cookie sheet. That's was this is and we didn't like it very much. We were expecting something more like a chocolate chip cookie.
More of a banana bread bite... exactly what I was looking for.

These are the BEST Banana Cookies I have EVER had. They are sweet, but not overpowering. And so soft with a nice crisp outside. 5 stars for sure and the PERFECT solution to overripe bananas when your tired of Banana Bread. Thank you for this recipe!
Really good except way too much baking powder/baking soda. Next time I‚Äôll make it with half of each.

I will make these cookies again and again! They are delicious.
I adjusted the oven temp to 355 and had to leave in a little longer because my oven scorched the cookies at 400, other than that the recipe is flawless and the cookies are delicious!
Thank you so much!
Followed the recipe. Very Good

Cookies are tasty, but next time I'll reduce the baking powder and sub brown sugar for 1/2 of the white sugar. Also, baking at 400 is crazy. I did my first batch at that temp and they burned after only 10 minutes. Reduced temp to 375 and baked for 11 minutes and they turned out well.
Like others, I did half and half white and brown sugar, and reduced the amount of baking powder to 1 tsp. They came out great.
Loved these cookies. I made them with 1/2 white and 1/2 brown Splenda. Also a tsp of cinnamon and 1/4 of nutmeg. Came out yummy.

Okay recipe. Had to make a few adjustments based on other reviews, including using only 1 tsp baking powder, 1/2 cup white sugar, and a little over 1/2 cup of the semisweet chocolate chips instead of the 2 cups it calls for. I added a 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/2 cup of chopped walnuts. I used three very ripe bananas and that came out to a little over 1 cup of mashed. I always substitute vegetable shortening for butter in every recipe, so that was a norm for me. I reduced the cooking temp to 350 and cooked them for about 13 minutes.

They turned out delicious!!!!!!! I am very happy with this cookie and will use this base + my alterations again and again, but I will probably lower the sugar amount just a tad next time and see how that turns out.

VERY cake-like. I wondered when I saw the excessive amount of baking powder used if the texture would be odd. It was.
Not cookie-like at all. The 'dough' is more like a batter. The flavor was 'meh'. I won't make these again unless I alter the ingredients somewhat; not why I choose to use allrecipes site.

Not thinking, I used two bananas and didn‚Äôt measure. Sooo. My happy accident = some delicious muffins rather than cookies. I lowered the temp to 350 and baked for 25-30 min. Not my original plan but pretty tasty just the same

I'm only giving 3 stars because I wouldn't call these cookies. They are basically cookie shaped banana bread. I could have just baked them in a bread pan. I love banana bread and this recipe tastes great, but I really wanted them to be more cookie like.
Good would make again!

10-16-19 Made these last night, my husband thought that they ok, nothing great. At first I thought the same, but the next day I thought they tasted much better. I think they r more like a breakfast pastry than a cookie.
I used mini chocolate chips. They‚Äôre delicious

I like the idea of bananas in addition to chocolate chips for these cookies. But, like many other reviewers have said, the cookies have a very cakey texture, probably too much baking powder? Also my first batch burned because I baked them at 400. Baked the second batch at 350 and they were better. Could also use some more banana.
I made these but used 1/2 cup white sugar and 1/2 cup brown sugar, also 1/3 cup butter and 1/3 cup peanut butter and added 1cup of oatmeal! Delicious!!! Thanks for the recipe
took the other reviewers advice and 1/2 cup brown and 1/2 white sugar just 1 spoon of powder and 1.5 banana. can't get enough of them lol. amazing recipe.
Excellent cookie!!
I personally don't care for chips in my cookies, but my wife said they was yummy. I did cut the amount of chips in half. I'm gonna do another batch and leave the chips out.

I followed other reviews and reduced baking powder, used half white/brown sugar, and used 3 ripe bananas. I also used 2 cups of whole wheat flour instead of all purpose flour as in the recipe. They are so good! Needed a few extra minutes in the oven as they're quite fluffy, but the extra time added a bit of a crunch to the bottom which is nice. Next time I'd want to try with even less sugar because they are quite sweet. Maybe use dates instead. Would definitely make again!!!

Followed the recipe and made no changes.It was very good. 
Will make it again.
Sorry, way TOO much baking powder. Looked like I'd made little cakes they were so puffy. Very little browning, not enough sugar.
I added 1tsp of cinnamon and split the sugar with white and brown sugar. My kids loved them!
These were tasty but for sure not cookies. More like muffin tops or oven pancakes but still taste good and quick and resourceful

As mentioned by someone else, these are very cakey, not sticky or chewy. That was ok for me, but they also came out very bland. They don't taste bad, but they're kind of dull, and barely any banana flavor. I often do lots of substitutions, but as I hadn't made them before and need to bring them to an event, I went by the recipe exactly as is. I will try them again in future but will substitute brown or coconut sugar for most of the white, and maybe also use a more flavorful flour blend with coconut and/or almond flour. I'd also use a lot more banana. But they are fine to have as a simple snack with coffee or tea.

I had 3 very ripe bananas , so I tried this recipe. My family loved them! Two changes I made though, I did turn down the oven temp to 350 degrees and used 1/2 white sugar and 1/2 brown sugar. You really do have to watch , because the tops stay very light, but the bottom gets brown quickly, so parchment paper works better for these. Also I did add 1 cup chopped pecans. Very soft cake like cookie.
Delicious! And so moist! I had only a cup of semisweet morsels so I supplemented with bittersweet morsels and together, they came out great!
No changes were made. Made a double batch. Absolutely delicious.

Love this! I followed the comment to make 1/2 c white and 1/2 c brown sugar, and only added 1 tsp baking powder. 

I also changed it up by adding 3/4 c ground flax seeds and it just added a little presentation texture and feel and really liked it. 

Also did a batch with the flax, and added nutmeg and cinnamon for flavor and a 1/4 c oil to make more dense and 1/2 c oats. These were my favorite variation. 

Really nice light cookie. Love making them small and bite sized!

These were very good. Sophia didn't want to try them bc of the banana. But she really liked them and kept sneaking more. I used 1 tsp baking soda, 1/2 c white sugar and 1/2 c brown sugar. *****The correct baking time for my oven is 7 min at 400 degrees.

OMG!!!! These were soooooooooo good!!!!!! The perfect cookie for my ‚ÄúHalf Good, Half Bad‚Äù mantra! Bananas and chocolate are a great combination. I used cacao dark chocolate. I would reduce the cook time because some of the cookies came out a bit overdone on the bottom.

These were quite good! Like a traditional chocolate chip cookie with a twist of banana. I followed the recipe exactly except I added a cup of crushed walnuts. The were moist and crunchy. I will make them again.
I followed the recipe. It's a nice cookie and a wonderful alternative to the usual banana nut bread. I will make it again.
No and yes
Very cool recipe, I enjoyed cooking this a lot. Bananas and chocolate is delist!
Have made this recipe multiple times and love it. I tend to use 3 mashed bananas and they turn out very fluffy and chewy. The people at my work love them.
My family's new favorite cookie recipe!!
Only had a couple bananas so halved the recipe. Worked very well. Baking time less stated in recipe. Very nice muffiny cookie!
Super good recipe! I took the advice from other reviews and they turned out amazing, directly out of the oven and the day after! Big hit with my friends and family. Thank you.

Really 400 degrees burned the first two dozen in about 10 minutes. 

Not that great.
I made a double batch. Used about a cup of mashed bananas more than what it called for and they turned out delicious and amazing. Big hit with the fam!

LOWER THE BAKING TEMP...400¬∞ Is ridiculously high for cookies. I made 1st batch at this, and of course they burned. 2nd batch I baked at 350¬∞ for 12 min, they were OKAY. I am not blown away, but, they'll knock out a sweet tooth. I upped the banana, and chocolate chips. still, very cake-like, and not overly amazing. Used my too-ripe bananas, so I am happy about that.

Ce sont des galettes moelleuses avecune texture de g√¢teau. Pour donner une tasse de bananes, il en a fallu 3 petites. Le go√ªt de la banane est bien pr√©sent. Elles sont √† refaire pour utiliser les bananes extra m√ªres, cela fait changement des pains et muffins aux bananes.
I only added 3/4 cup chocolate chips AND added 3/4 cup of chopped walnuts.....yummmmmm
I followed exactly what's written here, and I am happy with the results. Next time I will use riper bananas for distinct flavor. My son loves this.

Added 1 cup of Ancient Grains Oats. This is what I would call a soft cookie (cakey). When I dropped them by a spoonful on the pan I then used the bottom of a cup to flatten them a bit. It was an okay recipe, may make again. Made 4 dozen.
These cookies are now a household favorite! My husband calls them little banana breads, and i agree!
I made the cookies exactly as the recipe stated and they came out great!! I will definitely make them again!

These cookies are actually delicious, I decided to take my batch and put it into three parts, the first one I did just plain banana cookie, as my oldest boy doesn't like chocolate chips. The second batch I did with a healing huge tablespoon of peanut butter , And added peanut butter chipits . The third bowl was mixed in with chocolate chips as the recipe called for.

I turned my oven down because I found 400 was too hot as my oven cooks quickly, so I used it at 350¬∞and cooked the cookies for 12 minutes.

They turned out perfect, the plane banana ones taste just like a slice of banana bread and the other ones are delicious as well. The peanut butter is perfect in them
I have burnt the first pan, following the directions, so I turned the oven down and let them cook a bit longer
Husband rated this. Says they taste like mini banana cakes. Very dry and cakey but an excellent way to use up over ripe bananas. Followed directions to the tee. Needed something else (?)

I read previous reviews and did half cup white sugar and half cup brown sugar and lowered the baking powder to 1 teaspoon. I also made these into a bar cookie. I baked them at 350 degrees for 25 minutes and they were perfect.
